subtitle: Helping customers understand their energy journey

detailMetrics.label: Translated backend states like into human language
Customer has autonomy to understand their journey
From unreliable email system to just one click

contentBlocks.quote: Can somebody explain to me how this switching thing go?
contentBlocks.context: As a freelance & foreigner with zero knowledge of the British energy market, I had to piece together a system that even the engineers couldn't fully explain; then make it friendly enough for anxious customers waiting weeks for their switch.

blocks.html:
Switching energy suppliers in the UK can take weeks: That's just how it works.
So many cogs have to turn for things to happen (old supplier approves the transfer, industry databases get updated, meter readings verified...) and all needs to happen in the right order.
Most energy companies handle this by sending occasional email updates when customers hit major milestones. Simple enough, right?
But then something gets stuck and the time between emails stretches. Customers grow anxious flooding support lines (often for bottlenecks that aren't even the company's fault).

Tomato's specific mess?
Their email system was unreliable, and nobody could explain how the switching process actually worked.

items: Email notifications often failed to send
Customers had no way to check status except via direct contact
Support couldn't say "check your email" when emails weren't arriving
No documentation existed. Not for customer service, not for the rest of the company except backend

blocks.html: Double problem: customers had no visibility into an already opaque process, and support had no reliable way to help them.

contentBlocks.title: Building Knowledge from Fragments
contentBlocks.insight: No one could explain the full switching process; not customer service, not the backend team. As a non-UK resident, I had to learn the market from scratch while piecing together system knowledge that even the engineers couldn't articulate.
contentBlocks.result: Created acomprehensive documentation for the company of their own switching process.

contentBlocks.caption: What I created: Customer-facing journey broken into 5 understandable stages

contentBlocks.heading: From Email Chaos to Self-Service Diagnosis

before.label: The Old Way
items: Multiple (often failed) email notifications
"Did you get our email?" support tickets
No visibility into delays or bottlenecks
Customers in the dark about who was responsible for delays

after.label: The New Experience
items: One magic link email to personalised microsite
Direct real-time backend connection
Clear bottleneck diagnosis showing whose fault and why
Contextual actions for each state

blocks.html:
Bypassed company's unreliable email system entirely.
Instead of multiple (often failed) notifications throughout the journey, customers received one magic link to access their personalised tracking microsite—directly connected to the backend, always up to date.

blocks.text: Translated 15+ technical backend states into four human-readable stages:

items: Application — "We've received your switch request"
Switch Initiation — "Your current supplier has been notified"
Approval — "Good news! Your switch is approved for [date]"
Meter reading — "Collecting data! Your first bill will be issued by [date]."
Completion — "Welcome! You're now on Tomato"

blocks.html: Designed the interface to clearly show where delays were happening so client could take action (if needed on his side). "Your switch is delayed because your previous supplier/your bank/ the grid hasn't approved the transfer" beats silence or generic "processing" messages every time.

blocks.text: Built parallel experiences for different meter types, as their journey's were considerably different (more action required on traditional meters from customer):

items: Smart meters: Automated reading collection, fewer manual steps
Traditional meters: Clear callouts when manual readings were required

blocks.text: Created clear error messaging across three categories:

items: Application errors: Wrong MPAN, incorrect address, missing information
Switching errors: Debt objections, contract disputes, supplier blocking
Technical issues: Meter access problems, database mismatches, system failures

blocks.text: Each error included actionable next steps instead of vague "something went wrong" messages.
Added loading animations—tomatoes falling from the top, a small bouncing tomato at the bottom—to keep Tomato's playful personality alive during data fetches and make waiting feel less anxious.

contentBlocks.heading: Starting Point
contentBlocks.text: Stakeholders provided an initial draft showing their vision for the tracker—a simple vertical progress indicator. This became the foundation I built upon, adding error handling, dual journey paths, and brand personality.
contentBlocks.caption: Initial stakeholder wireframe

blocks.text: Before landing on the final design, I explored different ways to present the switching journey—testing information hierarchies, visual weights, and levels of detail disclosure.

imageFull.alt: Early design iterations showing different layout approaches
imageFull.caption: Early explorations: testing vertical vs horizontal flows, dropdown vs always-visible information

contentBlocks.title: Design as Documentation
contentBlocks.insight: The final prototype became the single source of truth for how Tomato's switching process actually worked—something no one at the company could explain before I started.
contentBlocks.result: Referenced by other teams after delivery. Sometimes the best way to get clarity is to start designing and let the process force the right questions.

blocks.text: Created a customer touchpoint that didn't exist before, turning an opaque industry process into something transparent and manageable.
Worked around unreliable email infrastructure by designing a single-link solution that gave customers direct backend access—no more "did you get our email?" support tickets.
Let customers see exactly where bottlenecks were and whose responsibility they were, eliminating unnecessary "where's my switch?" queries and reducing support burden.
Pieced together a complex system flow that no single person at the company could explain—starting from ground zero as a non-UK resident learning the British energy market.
Took scattered brand materials and evolved them into a cohesive, delightful tracking experience that felt unmistakably "Tomato."
Designed for mobile-only launch to get value in customers' hands quickly, proving that strategic constraints can accelerate delivery.

Key Takeaways: Engineers know more than they think
